3.17 Accounting and Data Control
Accounting and Data Control (

) Service officials and managers must communicate privacy and security standards to subordinate employees and establish methods to enforce them. and Security Employees are responsible for taking required precautions in providing privacy Taxpayer and security for the documentation, information, and property which they Returns and handle in performing official duties. (

) When using IDRS, only access those tax modules required to accomplish your official duties. All IDRS accesses are recorded for immediate review and to determine the accuracy of an adjustment. Any unauthorized access or browsing of tax modules by employees to satisfy personal curiosity or for fraudulent reasons are prohibited by IRS and are subject to disciplinary actions and/or dismissal from the Service. (

) While working assigned cases, SP employees may come across some that are blocked on IDRS. These cases can be identiﬁed by an IDRS security violation message, “Unauthorized Access to This Account”. If encountered, forward the case to your manager. Managers will notify the local Planning & Analysis Staff original case in a ﬁle awaiting access (can take up to ﬁve (
) business days). Once notiﬁed access has been granted, the case can be worked following ap- plicable procedures. (

) Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) data including Personally Identiﬁable Informa- tion (PII) and tax information, must be protected with encryption and/or access controls, limiting access only to approved personnel with a need to know. Refer to IRM

, Privacy and Information Protection, Privacy Policy for guidance on protecting and safeguarding the privacy of SBU data regardless of its format and when transmitting through email or Enterprise Electronic Fax (EEFax) system. If you suspect or know of a potential information loss, access the Report Losses, Thefts or Disclosures of Sensitive Data; Report Lost or Sto- len IT Assets and BYOD Assets website for instructions to report the loss of sensitive information/PII. (

) The Submission Processing (SP) sites work with the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) to resolve taxpayer issues. (
) Cases are sent to SP via Form
, Operations Assistance Requests (OAR). TAS’s goal is to provide high quality account resolution and to consistent application and enforcement of standards for taxpayers. (

) The responsibility of the Accounting Operation is to: • Monitor and control all TAS case ﬁles referred to Accounting. • Verify the accuracy and timeliness of the request. • Assign the TAS case to the correct team. • Quarterly, the designated employee will submit a report of all open aged TAS cases to management. ) This subsection describes the requirements for receiving, processing, ling and releasing Refund Litigation case requests. Litigation Cases (

) A taxpayer ﬁles a complaint in a suit for recovery of taxes. This is forwarded the appropriate Submission Processing Center (SPC) by a United States Attorney in district court cases, or by the Tax Division of the Department of Justice in Court of Claims cases. (

) To assist the Service in expediting retrieval of the necessary ﬁles, telephone contact (follow up via memorandum) is made by the offices indicated above. These calls provide pertinent information on the taxpayer and the tax liability. (
) Facsimiles (fax) and memorandums are received from both the District Counsel and Chief Counsel. (

) Instructions in this subsection referring to “Counsel” means either District Counsel or Chief Counsel. Note: All communications must come through Chief Counsel; it should not come from the Department of Justice. (

) The telephone call and a copy of the complaint should be received prior to facsimiles or memo from Counsel requesting the ﬁles. Send the requested formation to the requesting office (either District Counsel or Chief Counsel) using either certiﬁed or registered mail.

) Restitution is a legal remedy that can be ordered by the court, in a criminal case. A restitution order requires the criminal defendant to pay money or render services to victims or to redress the loss the defendant has inﬂicted. Normally imposed during sentencing, it can be agreed to by the parties in a plea agreement or imposed as a condition of probation or supervised (

) In a criminal tax case, the offense generally results in the loss of property, i.e., the money to which the government was entitled under the tax laws but which the defendant did not pay. Through a restitution order, a can require a defendant to pay money to the IRS to redress the losses he or she inﬂicted on the federal treasury. (

) In most criminal tax cases involving restitution, the amount of the tax loss is calculated from evidence admitted at trial or from information contained in plea agreement and presented to the district court at sentencing. (
) Since August
, the IRS has authority to assess and collect ordered in a tax case in the same way as if it were a tax. (
) Restitution should not be confused with civil tax liability. Internal Revenue Manual a # Only

3.17.243.7.9 (09-08-2022) Court Ordered Criminal Restitution Payments
Since August 16, 2010, the IRS has authority to assess and collect restitution ordered in a tax case in the same way as if it were a tax.

• The amount of the loss a defendant can be ordered to pay as must result from the defendant’s criminal activity and that amount generally does not include civil tax penalties. • A restitution order does not bar the IRS from determining civil tax liability in an amount greater than the amount ordered payable to the IRS as restitution. • A restitution order also does not prevent a taxpayer from challenging IRS’s determination that the civil liability exceeds the amount of the titution order. (

) Judgment and Commitment Orders (J & Cs) normally specify that defendants are to submit restitution payments to the office of the clerk of court in the district in which the defendant was sentenced. This includes restitution payments required to be paid to the IRS. (

) The clerk of court has the responsibility for receiving, processing, and recording restitution payments made by defendants. The clerk of court will forward the money (Treasury checks, personal checks, and/or money order) the victim(s) listed in the restitution order, which may include the IRS. Criminal restitution payments made to the IRS must be mailed to the address below. (
) The clerk of court offices will disburse criminal restitution payments to the IRS by issuing Treasury checks to the IRS. Effective October

Payments and credits posted to a civil tax account may contribute toward reducing the amount of restitution assessed. A duplicate assessment is when there is a Civil tax assessment in addition to the amount assessed as RBA, or when co-defendants are assessed restitution that relates to the or similar tax issues. The duplicate assessment amounts may or may not be equal dollar amounts. Cross-referenced payments and credits can be on an RBA module by TC
RC

, then apply the payment to the module and SBSE will reverse the TC
cross reference transaction. • If the transaction date of the restitution payment is after the date of the TC
, then do not apply the payment to the module as TC
transaction takes precedence.

Narrative Description A sentencing option in the federal courts. With probation, instead of sending an individual to prison, the court releases the person to the community and orders him or her to complete a period of monitored by a U.S. probation officer and to abide by certain condi- tions. A violation of probation can lead to revocation of probation and the imposition of a prison sentence. ″ ″ District court employees who work with offenders post-conviction, they’re tried and found guilty of federal crimes and also after they’re released from prison. They also help ensure that offenders released to the community obey the law rather than commit further crime. A public official who prepares and conducts the prosecution of persons accused of crime. In federal district courts, the prosecutor is usually an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the local U.S. Attorney’s Office. The purpose of the Questionable Refund Program (QRP) is identifying and developing schemes for the purpose of referring and supporting high-impact criminal tax and related ﬁnancial investigations. (Revenue Protection is no longer part of the QRP program). The of QRP is to investigate and prosecute promoters and conspirators foster conﬁdence in the tax system and enhance voluntary compli- ance. See IRM

, Questionable Refund Program. Only includes cases in which the IRS has requested the judgment. Does not include cases where the Department of Justice has counter-claimed and obtained judgment such as in

percent Penalty refund suits. Date on which defendant is released from prison. A defendant’s projected release date can be found on the Bureau of Prisons web site. The act of making good, or giving the equivalent for, any loss, damage or injury. Through a restitution order, a court can require a defendant in a criminal tax case to pay money to the IRS in order to redress losses he or she has inﬂicted on the Federal Treasury. The Return Preparer Program (RPP) involves claims on Federal tax returns prepared by unscrupulous return preparers who claim excessive deductions and exemptions on returns prepared for clients. The clients may or may not have knowledge of the excessive deductions and exemptions claimed. See IRM
